message: I'm excited to offer you this amazing product, and I think we can come to a mutually beneficial agreement. I'm willing to sell it to you for $12,000. What do you think?
Thanks for the offer, Alice. I'm interested, but $12,000 is a bit more than I'm comfortable with right now. How about we split the difference at $11,000?
I understand that $11,000 is a bit of a stretch for you, but I'm not willing to go that low. I'm willing to meet you in the middle at $12,500. What do you think?

Alice, I appreciate you meeting me halfway, but $12,500 is still a little too high for me. I'm willing to go up to $11,500.  This is a fair price for both of us, and I'm confident we can come to an agreement.

I'm not willing to go any lower than $12,500, but I'm willing to throw in some extras to sweeten the deal. I'll include a free premium service package worth $1,000. That brings the total value to $13,500. What do you think?

Alice, I appreciate the added value of the service package, but I'm still looking for a lower price on the product itself. I'm willing to pay $12,000, which includes the value of the service package. Let's find a solution that works for both of us.

I'm not willing to go any lower than $13,000, but I'm willing to throw in an additional service package worth $500. That brings the total value to $13,500. I'm confident this is a fair price for both of us. What do you think?

Alice, I appreciate you trying to work with me, but $13,000 is still higher than I'm comfortable with. My final offer is $12,500. This is a fair price that's within our budget and allows us to both get a good deal. If this doesn't work for you, I'll have to consider other options.

I understand you're trying to get the best deal, but I'm not willing to go any lower than $13,500. I'm willing to make one final concession: I'll include a 6-month warranty on the product, which is a $1,000 value. That brings the total value to $14,500. This is my final offer. What do you think?
